moves.1. e4 c5 2. f4 d6 3. Nf3 Nf6: we usually play d3, to counter Nf6, and then g3, Bg2, 0-0: but I decided on a different approach; this is one of the true beauties of GPA: there are more ways, to handle the opening...
moves.4. Bb5+ Nbd7 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 b5 7. e5: stronger than d3, b4, Nb1, Qb6...
moves.7... dxe5: b4, exf6, bxc3, fxe7, cxd2+, Nxd2, Bxe7, was a better try...
moves.8. fxe5 Ng4: again, after b4, exf6, bxc3, fxg7, cxd2+, Qxd2, Bxg7, Black would have been better off...
moves.13. d3 Qb6 14. O-O Bb7: there is more hope, in e6; as we will soon learn...
moves.15. Be3 Bxf3: b4, Nce4, was a better try...
moves.16. Qxf3 h6: last call for e6, or even g6...
moves.17. Nd5: I looked at Nge4, Qe6, Nxc5, Nxc5, Bxc5, b4, Na4, or at Qh3, Qc6, Nce4, g6, but didn't like it; this sacrifice will pay itself back, when accepted...
moves.17... Nxd5: the other option was Qd6 (Qc6??, Nxf6+, Qxf6, Qh3, and White is winning), Nxf6+, Nxf6, Ne4!, Nxe4 (what else; Black is also threatening Bxc5), Qf7+, Kd8, dxe4...
moves.19... Kc8: it is not hard to understand, that Black refuses to play Qxe6, Qxe6, and losing the Queen; but after Nxe3, Rf2, Rb6, Qh3, Nd5, Black has three light pieces and a pawn for the Queen: the upcoming deal is worse...
moves.20. Qe8+: of course, Qd8 is no solution, soon running into even mate: only move left being Kb7, with lots of problems ahead...
moves.20... Kb7 21. Qxd7+: White is setting the material score straight...
moves.21... Nc7: or Qc7, with the same result; after Ka8, Qxd5+, finishes it off...
moves.22. Nxc5+: best now is Ka8, Rf7, Re8, a4, b4, Nxa6, Qxa6, Qxc7, Rc8, Qxe5, Rxc2, Raf1, and it is over; Black didn't want any proof of this, and resigned...

gameName: Fierce Queening, in the Grand Prix...
